    Getting started with happifn

Getting started with happifn

Source: vignettes/getting_started.Rmd
getting_started.Rmd
library(happifn)

Get raw datasets

happifn can be used to retrieve raw data from permanent sample plots. Seven datasets are available. Their names can be retrieved using get_datasets_names() :

get_dataset_names()
#> [1] "arbre"     "bois_mort" "couvert"   "ecologie"  "flore"     "habitat"  
#> [7] "placette"

Then simply use the get_ifn() function to retrieve them. If no directory is specified, the data is seamlessly loaded into R from a url. If you wanna use a directory, “.zip” file from get_url() must be downloaded upstream and then unzipped in the same directory.

arbre <- get_ifn("arbre", dir = NULL)

Here’s a little trick for loading several datasets into memory at once :

datasets <- lapply(get_dataset_names(), get_ifn) |>
  setNames(get_dataset_names())

# Load all dataset to globalenv
list2env(datasets, envir = globalenv())

For a better understanding of how datasets are constructed, you can retrieve the metadata using get_ifn_metadata(). Three metadatasets are availables : “code”, “units”, “units_value_set”.

metadata <- get_ifn_metadata()

code <- metadata[[1]]

Get spatial datasets

The IFN also provides geographic layers grouping together different forest regions. As these layers are heavy, they are stored in another happifndata package. To load them, use check_happifndata(). For the moment, four data sets are available :

  • “ser” : sylvoecoregion;
  • “ser_ar” : sylvoecoregion d’alluvions recents;
  • “rfn” : regions forestieres nationales
  • “zp” : zone phytogeographiques
check_happifndata()
library(happifndata)

data("ser")
data("ser_ar")
data("rfn")
data("zp")
